title: Change year to 2020
body: Closes #37

title: Error: Cannot handle a <date> with year different than this year, and no month.  Using today's date.
body: <date year="2019" /> is causing the date error when converting xml to html using xml2rfc

title: Add Heng Liu to authors list
bump version
body:
Bump the version of the draft in preparation for submission.

This version picks up:
 - An editorial change related to pvds
 - A description of what to do when the captive portal URI changes.

title: Remove pvd lead-in
body:
PvD is almost certainly going to be published first, so remove the
lead-in to it in preparation for integrating the full rfc soon.

Fixes #29

title: API terminology consitency
body:
We were using CAPPORT API to refer to the API or the API server without
any real consistency. Clean this up by removing CAPPORT and using
API/API Server as the short forms for the Captive Portal API and Captive
Portal API Server.

I also removed all references to `CAPPORT`  from the architecture diagram. I think the only remaining "CAPPORT" occurrences refer to the architecture itself. Not sure what we want to do there.

Fixes Issue #31.

title: Remove nuisance from risks
body:
This was not phrased well. We decided in Montreal that we should
rephrase the title of the nuisance captive portal in the risks section.

Fixes Issue #24

title: Name of the API
body:
This is a little inconsistent.  I see "CAPPORT API" and "Captive Portal API", but mostly just "API" or "API server".

Having a short form (API) seems useful.  The longer form probably needs to be "Captive Portal API" to avoid having to define what "CAPPORT" means.  There seems to be value in distinguishing between the API and the entity that provides it, so maybe the latter distinction is fine to leave alone.

title: Describe what happens if the portal URI changes
body:
Just realized that, this section may also apply to the case of initial provisioning of Portal URI if multiple ways are used, such as:
DHCPv4/DHCPv6/RA could be used at the same time, and they return different values;

to quote 7710bis:
   However, if the URIs learned are not in fact all identical the
   captive device MUST prioritize URIs learned from network provisioning
   or configuration mechanisms before all other URIs.  Specifically,
   URIs learned via any of the options in Section 2 should take
   precedence over any URI learned via some other mechanism, such as a
   redirect.

Shall we mention anything on the initial provisioning case too here? or that will only in 7710bis?

title: PvD is going to be published first
body:
When the document says:

> Although still a work in progress, [I-D.ietf-intarea-provisioning-domains] 

It might be better to just remove the lead-in part, since it appears PvD will be published ahead of this document.

title: URLs should be context-free
body: Based on discussion in Singapore, the group decided to recommend (not require) that URLs use names that can be resolved from the public DNS (no split horizon, etc...).  The content served from those URLs should also not be dependent on the network path, but instead the URL would include all information necessary to produce the resource.

title: refresh capport architecture draft
body: The draft was about to expire. Bump the date and version.

title: Initial appendix work
body: As per the discussion on the doh and capport mailing lists, a first pass of describing at least two of the ways portals are detected.

title: DoH, split horizon, and captive portals
body:
In the case that access to an external DNS resolver is permitted, this could complicate the process of contacting the API server.  A recommendation to disable that might be wise.

(I only included the DoH thing in the title because everyone needs a DoH issue, but this is not really one of those.)

title: API=closed, network=open
body:
David Bird points out:

> The section titled  "Risk of Nuisance Captive Portal" should really be
> talking about networks that USE the API and have NO network integration
> (e.g. Captive by API only, not by any network enforcement function).

This is a case we might address.

We might reason about this by comparison with imperfect blocking.  Say that a network failed to block your VPN provider, you might see no problem with existing probes if you only used the VPN.  Though many network stacks seem to like to probe before allowing any traffic, this might still happen.

title: Remove entity reference for 2119
body: Just to see if circle likes this better.

title: Cleanup the figure
body:
The semi-colon and period annoyed me, so I decided to clean this up.

I didn't realize that you were putting the figure caption in the artwork.  That's not such a great idea.

title: Update PvD section
body:
We were incorrectly describing the behaviour of the capport PvD option.
Update the text to better reflect how it will work, and reference the
new draft describing that behaviour.

This removes most of the section describing the behaviour, since it's now in the new draft.

Fixes Issue #17.

title: Address non-binary blocking
body:
Point out that future Captive Portal Signalling Protocols will not
enable non-binary blocking.

Fixes Issue #13

title: Identity depends on network attachment point
body: Fixes Issue #12

title: Fix description of PvD usage
body:
This text incorrectly describes the PvD JSON as the API JSON. This is incorrect.

```
Although still a work in progress, [I-D.ietf-intarea-provisioning-domains] proposes a mechanism
 for User Equipment to be provided with PvD Bootstrap Information containing the URI for
 a JSON file containing key-value pairs to be downloaded over HTTPS. This JSON file would
 fill the role of the Captive Portal API described in Section 2.3.
```

We should also refer to the CAPPORT PvD proposal document which explains this.

title: Reduce scope of Signalling Protocol
body:
We decided to reduce the scope of the signalling protocol during ietf
102 in Montreal (Issue #14).This attempts to do so.

- Reduced signalling interactions from SHOULDs to a MAYs
- Removed references to trusting/validating/authenticating/etc the Signal
- reduced API extensibility text so that it no longer includes various unnecessary things, including 
  signal validation tokens
- Removed section on the "upgrade" path of sending signal in conjunction with redirecting
- changed a bit of language around to make it clear that the signal is truly optional
- Fixed a few nits
- Changed the "Conditions About to Expire" example to discuss the UE querying the API, rather
  than relying on a pre-emptive signals.

title: Describe what happens if the portal URI changes
body: Probably not a lot, except that future requests might go there.  Because we don't hold any state for these resources, that's probably OK.

title: Slim down the text on signaling
body: We concluded in Montreal to look at removing details of the signaling protocol that we haven't decided on yet.  For instance, we don't need to describe whether the signal is authenticated.

title: Address the non-binary cases
body: There are networks that want to selectively block things.  We aren't going to get consensus on whether that is good practice, but we do have consensus that we don't provide protocol mechanisms for communicating about selective blocking.  Document that fact.

title: Scoping of information
body: The information needs to only apply to the current point of network attachment.  That is obvious, perhaps, but worth stating.  Thanks to Warren Kumari.

title: Make sure there are no references to HTTP in the solution
body:
As pointed out on the mailing list, there's a few places we refer to an HTTP API. Make sure we don't do that.

>    This document aims to document consensus on the CAPPORT architecture.
>   DHCP or Router Advertisements, an optional signaling protocol, and an
>  HTTP API are used to provide the solution.  The role of Provisioning
> Domains (PvDs) is described.

title: Remove icmp
body: This PR attempts to deal with issue #8 by replacing references to ICMP with a generic signaling protocols, then specifying requirements for it.

title: Add identifier section
body:
We need to discuss what information will be used to identify the UE from
the perspective of the various components in the system. This updates
the draft to discuss this concept, including desired properties of the
identifier and some examples.

This aims to address issue 5  (https://github.com/capport-wg/architecture/issues/5)

title: What to do about ICMP
body: We need a firm decision about inclusion or not.  If we include it, then we need a doc defining mechanisms.

title: Update TLS wording to be stronger
body:
We want to make TLS a requirement, not a suggestion, so I've chagned
the wording around TLS to reflect this. I also added a section to the
security section discussing the motivation behind the requirement.

title: HTTPS
body:
It sure would be nice if we could mandate the use of HTTPS for the API.  It would be absolutely necessary if the API were used to exchange secrets.

HTTPS does make some things a lot harder.  Traps for the unwary lie in:

* OCSP or CRL validation which require that clients talk to servers that might not be on the whitelist (answer: use OCSP stapling or whitelist those names; the former being far better overall)
* non-unique names like those that use IP addresses or `.local` (possible answer: use real names)
* client clock skew that can't be corrected without contacting a blocked time server (rare but annoyingly hard to fix in practice)

title: Which portion of packet is used for capport enforcement?
body:
E.g., MAC address or IP address? Or?
Use of MAC address means enforcement must be on the local layer2 segment.
Use of IP address has complexity around the user device randomly changing the IPv6 address.

title: Mechanism to indicate "no captive portal"
body:
The current (RFC7710) DHCP option doesnt have a way to say theres no captive portal to talk to, so whenever we dont see it, well need to send a probe.
Giving a network a means of indicating there is no capport would improve connecting time.
Same for Provisioning Domains info.

title: Clarify Provisioning Domains capport representation
body: Does PvD mechanism deliver the capport state, or a pointer to the capport API, from which capport state is retrieved?

title: Deprecate or update RFC7710?
body:
RFC7710 is unclear on what kind of API is to be found at the URI conveyed in the DHCP option.
This could be clarified, OR deprecated if replaced by PvD.

title: Use i-d-template
body: Using these tools should help make things run a little more smoothly.  I'll setup a push to gh-pages if you think that this is a good plan.
